Subject: Re: [junit] How to count test assertions
In-reply-to: <avkncb+pand@...>

X-eGroups-Approved-By: nails762 <jbr@...> via email; 10 Jan 2003 15:57:04 -0000

This is likely to stir up some debate, because many tests can be 
written that don't require any asserts.  So a test shouldn't be judged 
by the number of asserts it uses.  (However, I have been in situations 
where I did flush out a test by adding more asserts and the fact that 
the output looked no different was somewhat disappointing.)

I'm tempted to say that the generated tests is what you should look 
into, rather than JUnit.  For example, if your generated test put 
something like this into the body:

throw new Exception("Test Not Yet Implemented");

Then you would have a complete TODO list of all the methods you've left 
to write tests for and wouldn't be receiving these false positives.  
But having a ton of errors coming from your tests isn't a great 
solution either.  It would be nice if JUnit provided a means for test 
generators to inform JUnit like so:

Auto generated tests might look like:

void testFoo() {
	throw new NotYetImplementedException();
}

Output might look like:

.......F
[/snip]
FAILURES!!!
Tests run: 8,  Failures: 1,  Errors: 0,  NYI: 302

-shane


On Thursday, January 9, 2003, at 12:51  PM, SteveKelem 
<s_kelem@...> wrote:

> JUnit (3.8.1) counts the number of test methods that pass/fail.
> With some of the test generation methods, such as JUnitDoclet, empty
> methods are generated (a good thing) for each class. But when the
> tests are run, the generated document shows that all these methods
> pass (questionably good).  This gives a false sense that the code
> being tested is being tested, when it really isn't because the test
> bodies are empty.
>
> Is there a way to track the number of assertions that pass/fail
> instead of the number of methods that are invoked in the test classes?
>  This way the numbers reported (e.g., 122 tests run) would tend to
> imply better test coverage, or at least more actual tests executing,
> rather than lots of empty tests running.  (Yes, I know bad tests can
> be written that skew the results, but we don't need to go into that
> now.)
> This way more the classes for which tests haven't yet been written,
> but the skeleton is up and running, would show up in the report as 0
> tests run, rather than whatever number of test skeletons have been
> generated
> and may or may not be empty.
>
> Thanks,
> Steve Kelem
subject: Re: [junit] How to count test assertions
